This appeal, on certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution, raises the question, whether Dhruvraj, respondent, on his adoption, divests the defend- ants-appellants of the properties- of his adoptive father and grandfather.

anchor.surface_text: An adopted son is held entitled to take in defeasance of the rights acquired prior to his adoption. on the ground that in the eye of law his adoption relates back, by a legal fiction, to the date of the death of his adoptive father, he being put in the position of a posthumous son.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution, raises the question, whether Dhruvraj, respondent, on his adoption, divests the defend- ants-appellants of the properties- of his adoptive father and grandfather.

holdings.text: An adopted son is entitled to take in defeasance of the rights acquired prior to his adoption on the ground that his adoption relates back by legal fiction to the date of the death of his adoptive father, putting him in the position of a posthumous son.

anchor.surface_text: An adopted son is held entitled to take in defeasance of the rights acquired prior to his adoption. on the ground that in the eye of law his adoption relates back, by a legal fiction, to the date of the death of his adoptive father, he being put in the position of a posthumous son.

holdings.text: As a preferential heir, an adopted son divests his mother of the estate of his adoptive father and divests his adoptive mother of the estate she gets as heir of her son who died after the death of her husband.

anchor.surface_text: As a preferential heir, an adopted son  a  divests his mother of the estate of his adoptive father and  b  divests his adoptive mother of the estate she gets as an heir of her son who died after the death of her husband.

holdings.text: A coparcenary continues to subsist so long as there is a widow of a coparcener capable of bringing a son into existence by adoption and the adopted son's rights are the same as if he had been in existence at the time of his adoptive father's death, prevailing over heir to the last coparcener.

anchor.surface_text: A coparcenary continues to subsist so long as there is in existence a widow of a coparcener capable of bringing a son into existence by adoption and if the widow made an adoption, the rights of the adopted son. are the same as if he had been in existence at the time when his adoptive father died

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle adduced from Shrinivas case applied to facts.

holdings.text: With reference to the estate of a collateral, inheritance can never be in abeyance, and once it devolves on the nearest heir it is not liable to be divested.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the claim with respect to the estate of a collateral, the governing principle is that inheritance can never be in abeyance, and that once it devolves on a person who is the nearest heir under the law, it is thereafter number liable to be divested.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle adduced from Shrinivas case, distinguished as inapplicable here.

holdings.text: Krishnabai's title to the property was defeasible on Tungabai adopting a son, and thus the appellants' claim under Krishnabai is defeasible on the adoption.

anchor.surface_text: But her title was defeasible on Tungabai, widow of Bandegouda, adopting a son to her husband. Vasappa and after him, his sons, inherited this property of Krishnabai and thus the appellants claimed under Krishnabai. Their such claim is therefore defeasible on the adoption of a son by Tungabai.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying coparcenary continuation and relation back doctrines from Shrinivas; property remained estate of adoptive father/grandfather passing through collateral (daughter).

holdings.text: The character of the property does not change from coparcenary to self-acquired property of Krishnabai so long as Tungabai exists and is capable of adopting a son who becomes coparcener.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, Krishnabai owned the property as full owner on the death of her father Narasappagouda, according to the Hindu law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hindu law in area allows full ownership to daughters but subject to coparcenary revival by widow's adoption power.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that this appeal should fail and accordingly dismiss it with companyts of this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above principles to facts leads to upholding High Court decree in favor of respondent.

precedents.citation: Shrinivas Krishnarao Kango v. Narayan Deviji Kango and Ors-  1

anchor.surface_text: Shrinivas Krishnarao Kango v. Narayan Deviji Kango and Ors-  1 . The principles to be adduced from what was said in this case may be summarised thus An adopted son is held entitled to take in defeasance of the rights acquired prior to his adoption.

precedents.case_name: Shrinivas Krishnarao Kango v. Narayan Deviji Kango and Ors
precedents.cited_proposition: An adopted son is entitled to take in defeasance of rights acquired prior to adoption by relation back to adoptive father's death; applies to adoptive father's estate but not collateral's estate; inheritance once vested cannot be divested.

anchor.surface_text: Amarendra Mansingh v. Sanatan Singh  2  .which related to an impartible zamindari. The last of its holder was Raja Bibhudendra. He died on December 10, 1922, unmarried. A companylateral, Banamalia, succeeded to the estate as the family custom excluded females from succeeding to the Raj.

precedents.cited_proposition: Adopted son can divest heir of adoptive brother holding the estate of adoptive father by relation back.
precedents.cited_holding: Amarendra could divest Banamali of the estate of Brajendra.

precedents.citation: Anant Bhikappa Patil  Minor  v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil 3

anchor.surface_text: Anant Bhikappa Patil  Minor  v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil 3 , this Court observed at page 24 When an adoption is made by a widow of either a companyarcener or a separated member then the right of the adopted son to claim properties as on the date of the death of the adoptive father by reason of the theory of relation back is subject to the limitation that alienations made prior to the date of adoption are binding on him, if they were for purposes binding on the estate.

precedents.case_name: Anant Bhikappa Patil Minor v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil
precedents.cited_proposition: Alienations prior to adoption binding if for estate purposes; no such safeguard for property inherited from collateral, title defeasible on adoption even for mesne holders and transferees.

precedents.citation: Ramchandra Hammant Kulkarni v. Balaji Datto Kulkarni,  4

anchor.surface_text: Ramchandra Hammant Kulkarni v. Balaji Datto Kulkarni,  4  which overruled the judgment in the instant case. The question formulated for the decision of the Full Bench was If on the death of a sole surviving companyar- cener his property has devolved upon his heir by inheritance and on his death it has vested in his own heir, would the subsequent adoption in the family of the sole surviving companyarcener divest it from such heir?.

precedents.case_name: Ramchandra Hammant Kulkarni v. Balaji Datto Kulkarni
precedents.cited_proposition: Subsequent adoption by widow does not divest property vested in heir of the heir of the last coparcener.
